details.standardTitle: A Note on Some Functional Relationships Involving the Mean Inactivity Time Order

p: Eva-María Ortega graduated obtaining the Award of Degree with special distinction in Mathematics, and received an MS, and a PhD in Mathematics, both from University of Murcia in Spain. Her research focuses on stochastic orderings, aging notions and dependence with applications in risk theory, reliability, and survival. Some of her other research interests lie in the areas of financial insurance portfolio modeling, and applied operational research. Currently, she is leading a research project at the Centro de Investigación Operativa (CIO) at the University Miguel Hernandez in Spain, and is an Associate Professor at Department of Statistics, Mathematics, and Computer Science at this university.

authors.affiliation: Centro de Investig. Operativa, Univ. Miguel Hernandez, Orihuela
authors.name: Eva-MarÍa Ortega

details.abstract: Stochastic comparisons from inactivity times have been used in several reliability problems. The inactivity time represents the interval time elapsed after an event occurs until the time of its observation, and it is useful to predict the exact times of occurrence of events. We obtain a characterization of the reversed hazard rate order, and a functional relationship involving the mean inactivity time order for non-negative random variables that model lifetimes. Also, we obtain comparison results of two random sums based on their mean inactivity times, which allow us to select a better engineering system subjected to a general shock model. Our results provide other applications in reliability, statistics, and risk theory.

Take two absolutely continuous random variables \$X\$, and \$Y\$; with supports \$(l_{X},u_{X})\$, and \$(l_{Y},u_{Y})\$; distribution functions \$F_{X}\$, and \$F_Y\$; reversed hazard rates \$a_{X}\$, and \$a_{Y}\$; and mean inactivity times \$m_{X}\$, and \$m_{Y}\$, respectively. \$X\$ is said to be smaller than \$Y\$ in the

1)reversed hazard rate order (denoted by \$X\leq_{\rm rhr}Y\$) if, for all \$t\in(\min(l_{X},l_{Y}),+\infty)\$, \$X_{(t)}\geq_{st}Y_{(t)}\$, or equivalently, \$a_{X}(t)\leq a_{Y}(t)\$ (see Shaked & Shanthikumar [15]); and
2)mean inactivity time order (denoted by \$X\leq_{mit}Y\$) if, for all \$t\in(l=\min(l_{X},l_{Y}),+\infty)\$, \$m_{X}(t)\geq m_{Y}(t)\$, or equivalently, \$(\int_{l}^{t} F_{X}(u)du/\int_{l}^{t}F_{Y}(u)du)\geq (F_{X}(t)/F_{Y}(t))\$ (see Finkelstein [3] or Nanda et al. [19]).
The reversed hazard rate order strictly implies the mean inactivity time order (see Ahmad et al. [4], and Finkelstein [3]).
